comments.commentBody: I totally agree with your line of reasoning. This is where people confuse economics and human behavior, which you seem to have gotten down well!!!

I'm sure the members of the Board of Health have all read plenty on the behavioral side of the equation and know this is where the answer lies. Think about books like Nudge and Thinking, Fast and Slow. Many bad choices people make are not about knowledge at all. Think about your own moments of weakness, and you know it's true. It's not that you don't know what's wrong with large orders of french fries or chocolate chip cookies at big as your head. I've known nurses and librarians who suffer from entirely preventable health issues.

The idea here was to create a natural trigger for better health: make it harder but not impossible to get large quantities of a sugary drink. If you make it easier to choose something better, people do. If a vending machine has yogurt and almonds, that's what people will buy. We are naturally lazy about our long-term thinking in this way.

Is this a pure violation of personal freedom? Seems more like a manipulation of our natural tendencies than anything. Perhaps it is simply too difficult to slap beverage companies and other junk food purveyors with taxes earmarked for public programs in obesity based on the percentage of their product line that exceeds the sugar-salt-fat threshold. Cigarettes and alcohol kill, so we tax them. If so-called "food" kills, I would guess the same rules could apply, and we could begin by not calling this stuff food. People might be less happy about eating and drinking something clearly labeled a "calorie vehicle."

Bill, I am a partner in a heterosexual marriage, and I think same sex marriage affirms and enlarges the sense of faithfulness and trust one expects from marriage.

It seems that many who appose same sex marriage see marriage itself as a child-bearing chore rather than creating a joint pursuit of happiness with another person.

Social conservatives' opposition to gay marriage isn't about gays. It's about heterosexual women.

The men who run the Catholic church and other social conservatives are out-front about this. They believe that men and women are "naturally" suited to certain rigid gender roles--men as the leaders and breadwinners, women as the submissive nurturers and child caregivers.

If two gay men or two lesbians can marry and successfully raise children, the gender stereotypes so crucial to the worldview of social conservatives are proven to be invalid. And if one of their faith-based principles is debunked, all of them are called into question. They panic and lash out in a way that looks irrational to the rest of us.

Bill points out that "all citizens have the right to obtain this privileged status (marriage) by simply choosing to marry someone of the opposite sex regardless of their so-called sexual orientation." This may be the silliest thing I've ever read in the New York Times. Gay people already can marry. They just have to marry someone they don't want to have sex with. Abstinence within marriage--taking social conservatism to the next level.

Once again, Linda Greenhouse has done a masterful job of context-setting by citing obscure litigation to show an issue has developed. Now, in response to blackcatbone: Exactly. In all the furor over this issue, no reporter has confronted opponents of same-sex marriage to ask how it poses a threat to opposite-sex marriage. Failure to pose this question is a major shortcoming of all the journalism on this issue. Asking the question doesn't mean the reporter is taking sides; it simply means he/she won't let the interviewee get away with the same old bromide.

And what with the new reversible vasectomies, there's really no excuse for men to have "unwanted children" anymore, so I hope and assume, Matt, given your extremely negative attitude toward the whole enterprise, that you will not be "producing" any kids that some benighted woman might actually expect you to pay for.

Now, even if a man doesn't earn as much as a woman (not no money at all-- just not as much), he suddenly gets much less attractive as a mate. One needs to group the GOP mind-influencers. Lee Atwater, Karl Rove, David Keene, Jim DeMint, Thomas Donahue, Mitch McConnell, Roger Ailes, Halley Barbour, and Rupert Murdoch. You also have Glen Beck, Rush Limbaugh, and a dozen other talk radio and conservative TV shows hosts who slam daily. The Hannity and O'Reilly evening diatribes, Sarah Palin, Ann Coulter, the new agitator Ted Cruz, Grover Norquist, James Bopp, Rick Santorum and the great dark prince Newt Gingrich.

Collectively these men, and its mostly men, have worked to develop a conservative alternate universe that their acolytes live within. It has been done with intent and precision. It is a dark force.

It operates by appealing to human nature and stroking the emotions of its targets again and again. It's a complex enterprise that has evolved into a propaganda effort greater than what happened in Germany between 1933 and 1945. It began with Nixon in the 60s.

It's the only way the GOP can operate. Its leaders believe that there is not a fairly large center but that rather there is a divide and that is the task of this propaganda engine. It claims the liberal or left-wing media do not give fair time to the conservative right.

There is a reason for this. When you comp the output of the GOP propaganda engine and each spokesperson’s statements and credentials, one does not find caliber, character, or fact-based reasoning. There is only one-sided artfully-constructed discourse intended for a disparate coalition.

I'm the single mother of a son who has a good marriage, two boys, a business of his own, My son is successful--hard-working, creative, but highly stressed because he is so committed to being successful. He always worked hard, from too early an age--a result of anxiety over financial stress on his mother. This economy hurt his business-- like everyone who is suffering at the hands of a government dragging us through misguided wars & a banking fiasco that dragged us down further. Survival stress already exists for much of our population--it's now compounded.

Divorce wasn't a happy choice for me, but it meant not living in a miserable household. Instead we lived in a household of financial anxiety. It still hurts that I couldn't provide more security. I still worry about the stresses that resulted from this kind of childhood. Sadly we can't all have the ideal.

I'm so proud of my son--he's a good man, hard-working, loves his wife & children, does well by them. Our situation was heart-breaking to me & I was only too conscious of my part in that suffering. We came through--we survived, & reasonably well. I wonder if the damage inflicted by our government and banking industry was considered in the above study? When the American economy sinks, one must be extraordinarily strong to get through it. While I understand the study, the young, vulnerable (vulnerability is caused by so many things) the poor, elderly, the older middle aged, regular families--ALL have a hard time.

The closing comment assumes the issue of men not being married to the mothers of their children is because they're not attractive enough to these mothers. Is it possible though that the reason they're not is just that they (ie, men) don't want to be married at all? Marriage is a high-risk behavior for men. Like owning and riding a motorcycle? Not quite. But being married places men in a very explicit legal risk that was not an issue until divorce became a lot easier and judges decided to clobber men in the process by awarding/rewarding women for divorce by trucking huge amts of men's earned assets and income over to them even if they never worked a day outside the house. Marriage simply is a far less attractive proposition for many men these days, whether they have college degrees and/or make a lot of bank or not.

I wonder with all the ppl quoted in this article, has anyone actually tried to engage the kind of men they're concerned with (I imagine, 20-30 year-old single men) and actually *ask* them where they're at with this topic? It seems there's a lot of speculation going on here, not a lot of actual data acquired from the source.

Not sure New York City is the salvation of NBC late night. Jay Leno does feel like he's doing a Las Vegas schtick so I understand the older audience attraction and unwillingness to accept change. I admire Letterman but sometimes his grumpiness is too much to swallow before bedtime. Kimmel and Fallon offer a hipper and younger form of comedy--I think they are both equally talented in their own unique way. While I don't underestimate the importance of delivering jokes with great timing, let's not forget the voices behind every late night host: the writers and producers--these are the real foundation for any successful show.

I would be very worried if I were NBC. The replacement of Leno with Fallon is going to alienate a huge chunk of the loyal and mostly older Tonight Show audience. The fragmentation of television viewing accelerates each year. Content competition from cable and watching programs on a plethora of new tech devices and from new sources like the web are making live television viewing nearly as obsolete as VCRs. Creating new show buzz is a lot more difficult than it used to be so Mr. Fallon will have his work cut out for him.
